The rear camera setup includes a 50MP primary camera with OIS, a 32MP telephoto camera, and an 8MP ultra-wide camera. The front sports a 32MP selfie camera. The primary camera captures bright photos with close-to-reality colour reproduction, while low-light shots are natural and vibrant. Running on ColorOS 14, based on Android 14, the phone offers a range of features and customisations. Overall, the OPPO Reno11 Pro is a solid choice for those seeking a stylish phone that handles multitasking well and comes with impressive cameras.

The iPhone 11 is a good option for people looking to explore the Apple ecosystem because even though it costs as much as Android flagship phones, the price is significantly lower than the iPhones of the last two years. The iPhone 11 also introduces night mode on an iPhone for the first time and the battery life is also a lot better than previous models.

The Samsung Galaxy S20 FE 5G looks exactly like its 4G model with no design changes. In terms of design, the S20 FE 5G has a very clean and minimal look with a plastic back panel. This phone is powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 865 SoC, which-- albeit slightly dated--handles day-to-day tasks with ease, including running heavy games like Call of Duty: Mobile. The S20 FE 5G runs on Samsung's One UI 3.1, which is based on Android 11. This device comes pre-loaded with numerous apps, though users can uninstall them based on their preferences. As for the display, there's a 6.5-inch Super AMOLED display that provides a natural look and accurate colours. While indoor brightness is satisfactory, outdoor visibility might be lacking.  Powering the device is a 4500mAh battery, supporting up to 25W of fast charging; disappointingly, it ships with a 15W charger. The camera setup includes a 12MP wide-angle camera, an 8MP telephoto camera, a 12MP ultra-wide camera at the back, and a 32MP selfie shooter at the front. Daylight captures are crisp and vibrant, though low-light performance is average. The Samsung Galaxy S20 FE 5G caters well to casual users seeking a 5G-enabled device for their daily usage despite its older processor, making it a suitable choice for their needs.
The Vivo X100 captures dazzling photos, boasts a gorgeous display, and packs a marathon battery, but a slightly plasticky build and buggy software hold it back from becoming the ultimate flagship
The Xiaomi 12 Pro has managed to undercut its rivals and punch above its weight thanks to a brilliant camera setup and top-notch hardware.

The Redmi 12 is that affordable 5G kid on the block, offering decent bang for your buck. It packs in 5G compatibility, solid battery life, and a respectable display for its price tag. With a spacious 6.79-inch FHD+ LCD display rocking a smooth 90Hz refresh rate, your visuals are crisp and fluid indoors, though it might struggle a bit under bright sunlight. In the camera department, you're looking at a 50MP main shooter and a 2MP depth camera - no ultra-wide camera here, unfortunately. Selfie-wise, there's an 8MP front-facing camera. While it holds its own in well-lit conditions, low-light shots leave something to be desired. It's powered by the Snapdragon 4 Gen 2 SoC, chugging along smoothly for your everyday tasks but stumbling a bit when it comes to gaming. With a hearty 5000mAh battery, it's got the juice to keep you going through the day. It runs on MIUI 14, based on Android 13, but be prepared for a bit of bloatware out of the box. At Rs. 11,999, this 5G smartphone checks off most of the boxes, making it a worthy contender for budget-conscious buyers.
Vivo T2 Pro is a great budget smartphone for users who value style and premium design. While the camera may not be its strong suit, it definitely delivers on performance and battery life.

The Poco M6 Pro's design language is minimal and stunning. It's lightweight yet sturdy, a great combination. The phone boasts a 6.71-inch FHD+ display with a 90Hz refresh rate, offering good brightness indoors and outdoors. It features a 50MP primary camera, a 2MP depth camera on the back and an 8MP selfie camera on the front. The camera performs well in daylight, though edge detection in portrait mode could be improved. The phone is powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 4 Gen 2 SoC, which easily handles multitasking, though it may not excel at intensive gaming. Running on MIUI 14 based on Android 13, the device comes with pre-installed apps. The M6 Pro 5G has a 5000mAh battery and includes a 22.5W charger in the box. The phone can last an entire day with light usage, but moderate to heavy usage will require charging by the end of the day. The Poco M6 Pro offers good battery life, smooth everyday performance, and impressive image quality in daylight conditions.

At a starting price of Rs 66,999 (8GB RAM + 128GB storage), the OnePlus 10 Pro goes up against a host of premium devices in India. It brings a lot to the table - Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 chip, 80W fast charging support and the adapter ships with the phone, 6.7-inch QHD+ display, and 48-megapixel triple camera setup. Not to forget, the OxygenOS is here to stay and is a popular Android skin.      Some of the biggest strengths of the device are its performance, display, battery, and primary camera are among the best out there. Unfortunately, we can't say that for all sensors. The ultra-wide camera, in particular, doesn't impress. But, then, the missing IP rating is slightly a heartbreak. It's a feature that is always good to have. Not to forget, OnePlus will also need to tighten its update cycle for both OS and security updates. We also think that it's about time that OnePlus starts shipping a 512GB storage variant with its flagship phones.

The iQOO Z7 Pro boasts an attractive design and a gorgeous display but lacks stereo speakers. Its cameras perform well, but lack an ultra-wide angle option. On the positive side, it offers excellent performance for gaming and multitasking, efficient screen time, and quick charging. You can also consider the Lava Agni 2 for a lower price with an ultra-wide camera, or the Redmi K50i for enhanced performance in this price range.

Motorola's G54, priced at Rs 15,999, impresses with its robust battery life and a commendable 12GB RAM variant, catering to heavy users. However, the LCD display may deter some, especially avid entertainment lovers. The audio quality does stand out, and performance is reliable for daily use or light gaming. That said, the one-year software promise disappoints, considering the cut-throat competition in the segment. For faster charging, OnePlus Nord CE 3 Lite or Realme 11 5G come across as better options in this price range.

The Galaxy Z Fold 6 refines its design with a more ergonomic, lightweight build and a slightly wider cover screen. The less prominent crease and increased brightness enhance usability. While it maintains the same battery capacity, it performs well and features improved AI tools for browsing and note-taking. However, it retains the previous generation's cameras and charging speeds. For better camera and charging options, consider the Vivo X Fold 3 Pro or OnePlus Open. For advanced AI, the Z Fold 6 is ideal.

The Phantom X2 5G breezed through our day-to-day usage and our gaming sessions. It has an inconsistent set of cameras that needs fixing. Besides that, the device has a good battery life, but slow charging is a bummer. This aggressive pricing could bear some fruit for Tecno.

The Pixel 7 Pro is available at Rs 84,999, a bargain for a flagship so clean, capable and reliable if you ask us. So if owning a Pixel phone was always on your bucket list, the Pixel 7 Pro might make the cut for you.

The Xiaomi Mi 11T Pro 5G comes with a 6.67-inch AMOLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate. The smartphone uses an octa-core Snapdragon 888 SoC, and packs 8GB of RAM. The device takes some good images, thanks to a 108MP triple-camera setup. The smartphone has a long lasting battery life and a 120W fast charging support. The device lacks a 3.5mm audio jack and a microSD card slot. Overall, the  Xiaomi 11T Pro 5G is a good smartphone in the Rs 40,000 price range, which you should consider buying.

Pixel 6a is excellent choice for those who love stock Android experience. Google promises multi-year software update cycle which is a great addition. The Pixel 6a can handle most intensive tasks but isn't ideal for hardcore gamers.

OPPO Reno 10 Pro impresses with stunning design, a premium glass finish, and camera performance, easily outclassing OnePlus and iQOO rivals. However, its high price lacks stereo speakers, includes unwanted bloatware, and offers only average battery life without any IP rating. While it may suit those seeking style and photography prowess, better alternatives like the OnePlus 11R, iQOO Neo 7 Pro, and OnePlus Nord 3 overshadow it, making recommending the Reno 10 Pro difficult.

The Vivo V29e, while expensive for its performance, boasts Vivo's premium design, a strong camera, excellent battery, and an accurate display. However, the underwhelming Snapdragon 695 hinders long-term usability.

Priced at under Rs 35,000, the OPPO Reno 10 is an excellent 5G handset which comes with an AMOLED display. The display panel has 120Hz refresh rate and thin bezels. The device is powered by Dimensity 7050 SoC, which is downgrade from the Dimensity 1300 which the Reno 8 5G uses. The smartphone supports 67W fast charging and offers a good battery life. However, the camera performance on the device is average, and the handset also comes with many pre-installed apps. If you are looking for some other options in the same price range, then devices such as iQOO Neo 7 Pro, OnePlus Nord 3, POCO F5, and the Motorola Edge 40 offer more value for money.

The Redmi Note 12 and Note 12 Pro+ share the same design. The phone is comfortable to hold and provides a good grip. It features a 6.7-inch AMOLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate, offering a good viewing experience with smooth and fast animations. The phone is powered by a 5000mAh battery and comes with a 33W charger, easily lasting a day with moderate to heavy usage. The device runs on Android 12, which is disappointing since the latest version, Android 13, should be included. The Note 12 is equipped with the Qualcomm Snapdragon 4 Gen 1 SoC. It performs moderately well for day-to-day tasks, but games crash too frequently in gaming. The rear camera setup consists of a 48MP primary camera, an 8MP ultrawide camera, and a 2MP macro camera. Daylight shots are acceptable and have good colour accuracy, but the ultrawide camera could do with some improvements. On the front, there's a 13MP selfie camera with various beauty modes and filters, producing consistently nice skin tones. Considering these factors, the Redmi Note 12 is a good smartphone with a solid design, decent performance, and impressive cameras.

OnePlus 11 5G, at a starting price of Rs 56,999, will be a tough flagship to beat this year. It offers excellent performance, charging, and camera capabilities. The 100W fast-charging support is definitely the cherry on the cake, while promised 4 years of Android updates make users future-ready.

The Infinix Hot 50 delivers solid performance, a clean UI, impressive low-light photography, and a long-lasting battery. Its attractive design and strong build quality are major pluses. However, it does have some drawbacks, like issues with saturation and contrast, plus slow charging. Overall, it's a dependable choice for a well-rounded smartphone, but if daylight camera performance is crucial for you, the Realme C65 might be a better fit.

The Galaxy S10 may very well be the best and most complete flagship smartphone of 2019. It has all the features and specifications one could think of, and its pricing is also not as outrageous as some of its competitors. The S10 is also pretty much the same phone as the larger S10+, thus offering better overall value.

The OnePlus Nord CE 4 5G features a pill-shaped camera module and a solid back panel. Although the back panel is plastic, it gives the phone a glass-like feel. The phone boasts a 6.7-inch AMOLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate, offering a smooth and fast scrolling experience and a vivid and punchy viewing experience. On the rear, a 50MP primary camera is paired with an 8MP ultra-wide camera, while the front houses a 16MP selfie camera. The camera quality is good in both bright and low-light conditions, though skin tones tend to be slightly beautified. The phone is powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 7 Gen 3 SoC and delivers satisfactory performance. It handles demanding games like BGMI without overheating during extended use, a positive feature. The OnePlus Nord CE 4 has a robust 5500mAh battery and a 100W SUPERVOOC charger. The phone can last at least 24 hours with light to moderate use. Besides its design, this phone excels in various aspects.

The Google Pixel 7 features a 6.3-inch FHD+ OLED display with a refresh rate of 60Hz to 90Hz. The display offers vibrant colours and a pleasant viewing experience. The Pixel 7 has a solid build quality, though it can become uncomfortable to hold after long periods. The stereo speakers deliver excellent volume and clarity. In terms of cameras, the Pixel 7 includes a 50MP wide camera, a 12MP ultra-wide camera on the back, and a 10.8MP selfie camera on the front. The camera app offers a variety of features, including Magic Eraser, Photo Unblur, and Cinematic Blur. The image quality of the wide camera is impressive, but the ultra-wide camera's results are too narrow compared to other smartphones. The Pixel 7 is powered by the Tensor G2 SoC, which handles everyday tasks smoothly. However, extended gaming sessions can cause the back panel to heat up. The phone has a 4355mAh battery, smaller than the Pixel 6's. It runs on Android 13 out of the box and will be among the first to receive the Android 14 update. The software provides a stock Android experience with excellent features. If you're looking for a flagship device with good cameras, great features, a stock Android experience, and reliable performance for daily tasks, the Pixel 7 is an excellent choice.

The Realme GT 2 Pro comes loaded with the top-of-the-line Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 processor that delivers top-grade performance. The phone also comes loaded with a top-notch display that makes video consumption a delightful experience. The device, on the downside, has no wireless charging support and no IP rating. That said, if you are looking for a flagship smartphone on a budget and want a unique design, then Realme GT 2 Pro can be considered a good option.

The iPhone 15 Pro, while lacking revolutionary changes, impresses with its USB-C port, titanium build, and A17 Pro chip, built on industry-first 3nm process. The display is stunning, featuring high brightness and a faster refresh rate for smooth use. Despite minor camera upgrades, the portrait mode and focal length additions are noteworthy, though post-processing consistency needs improvement. The phone falls short in maximising the true potential of USB Type-C (but it is finally here!), lacks faster charging, and offers an average battery life. That said, the iPhone 15 Pro is a perfect example of there is more to it that meets the eye. While the iPhone 15 Pro may feel pricey at Rs 1,34,990, it is a reliable and powerful compact option that takes forward the legacy of its predecessors in the right direction.

The Redmi Note 12 Pro is a sweet deal at Rs 24,999. It manages to perform similarly to its elder sibling at a cheaper price, while also providing some value-for-money features over the Realme 10 Pro+.

The Realme 12 5G flaunts a chic back panel design, handles daylight photography reasonably well, and boasts a robust chipset for its price bracket. Its 6.72-inch LCD display boasts a 120Hz refresh rate and holds its own, although it tends to falter under direct sunlight. Powered by the MediaTek Dimensity 6100+ SoC, it breezes through light tasks but falls short for hardcore gaming enthusiasts. Running on Realme UI 5.0, based on Android 14, it offers customisation options but comes loaded with pesky bloatware apps. When it comes to photography, it sports a 108MP primary camera alongside a 2MP portrait camera on the rear, complemented by an 8MP selfie snapper. The resulting photos are decent, perfect for social media sharing, with colours that pop naturally. Equipped with a 5000mAh battery with support for 45W fast charging, it can easily last a full day with moderate usage or endure around 6-7 hours of heavy usage. For the accident-prone, investing in a sturdy case is advisable to prevent unfortunate slips. Overall, the Realme 12 5G exudes budget-friendly sass while delivering a commendable blend of style and camera prowess.

The Motorola Edge 40 is a premium offering from Motorola priced at under Rs 30,000. This latest Edge series smartphone flaunts a 6.55-inch pOLED display with a Full HD+ resolution and a 144Hz refresh rate. Thanks to an octa-core Dimensity 8020 processor, the device offers excellent performance. The rear camera performance on the device is also good. However, in low-lighting conditions, the front-facing camera captures average images. Also, the device lacks a microSD card slot. Overall, the Motorola Edge 40 is a decent smartphone at Rs 29,999, considering that you get an OLED 144Hz display, Dimensity 8020 SoC, up to 68W fast charging, 5G, and a 50MP dual-camera setup.

The Motorola Edge 40 Neo, priced at Rs 20,999, impresses with its premium design, curved AMOLED display, and rare-for-this-segment IP68 rating. The phone offers a smooth user experience with two-year guaranteed software support. The Edge 40 Neo also boasts decent battery life paired with fast charging and usable cameras. If you are looking for an all-rounder device around Rs 20k, the Motorola Edge 40 Neo is a perfect buy.

The HMD Fusion is perfect if you crave a unique, repair-friendly design and clean UI with minimal bloatware. It offers solid battery life and a standout camera for capturing memories. However, its display falls short for multimedia enthusiasts, and its performance lags behind competitors in its price range. If performance is a priority, consider the iQOO Z9x instead.

The Vivo Y200 5G caters to those who prioritise staying stylishly up-to-date while constantly on the move. The Eco-Fiber leather makes the phone look modern and chic. It comes with a 5000mAh battery that can extend usage up to a full day. This device has a 50MP primary camera, a 2MP bokeh camera, and a flicker sensor. It delivers adequate picture quality during the day, albeit with a tendency to over-brighten faces. However, its edge detection capabilities leave room for improvement. The performance from the Qualcomm Snapdragon 4 Gen 2 SoC isn't the best in class, so, If performance and gaming rank high on your priority list, you might want to explore other options. Nevertheless, considering its price point, you get a really nice 120Hz AMOLED display along with good dual stereo speakers. The UI is decent but keep an eye out for bloatware on this smartphone.

Priced at Rs 13,999, the Itel S23 Plus comes with an AMOLED display. The display panel has a Corning Gorilla Glass 5 protection. The smartphone also has an in-display fingerprint sensor and a NFC support. A 5,000mAh battery equipped with the device can easily last throughout the day. However, the performance of the device is average and it lacks 5G support. If 5G and a higher refresh rate aren't a concern for you, you can consider buying the Itel S23 Plus.

The Moto G24 Power boasts a clean user interface, impressive battery life, and an IP52 rating for splashes. However, it falls short in the 5G compatibility department. Display-wise, its 6.56-inch IPS LCD screen offers a 90Hz refresh rate, though its performance under bright sunlight is somewhat lacklustre for its price range. On the camera front, users are equipped with a 50MP main camera, a 2MP macro snapper, along with a 16MP selfie shooter. While the camera setup delivers decent results, it may not satisfy users seeking crisp details, and the selfie camera tends to overly smooth the skin, yielding an artificial appearance. Powered by the MediaTek Helio G85 chipset, the Moto G24 Power suits regular usage but may struggle with high-end gaming demands. Thankfully, its Android 14-based My UX interface provides a nearly stock Android experience with minimal pre-installed apps, coupled with extensive customization options. The smartphone is powered by a 6000mAh battery that should last for an entire day. So, if you're okay with skipping the 5G hype and can live with some average camera action, the Moto G24 Power could be your budget-friendly companion.

The Vivo V27 looks aesthetically pleasing and is UV-reactive, changing the colours under glaring sunlight. When indoors, it returns to its normal colour. It changes colours like a chameleon. The device boasts a 6.78-inch, curved AMOLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate. The display is highly responsive and buttery smooth. However, this phone lacks stereo speakers, which can be a dealbreaker for many. The phone features a MediaTek Dimensity 7200 SoC, which performs well in day-to-day usage. Gaming on this phone is also good, but you may notice occasional lags and stutters when playing intensive games. The phone packs a 4600mAh battery and comes with a 66W charging adapter. The charging speeds are decent. The Vivo V27 runs on FunTouchOS 13, based on Android 13, which comes with bloatware. The V27 offers good customisation options for the home screen and lock screen. At the rear, there's a 50MP main camera with OIS, an 8MP ultra-wide camera, and a 2MP super macro camera. On the front, there's a 50MP camera with autofocus for selfies. The main camera on this phone is brilliant; however, the ultra-wide and super macro cameras need some improvement. The front camera clicks selfies that can be posted on social media without any editing. Therefore, if you're in the market for an aesthetically pleasing device that changes colours like a chameleon, and you want an awesome battery with great cameras, then the Vivo V27 stands as an ideal choice.

Realme 11 Pro offers notable upgrades, including a premium faux leather finish and a vibrant curved display for an enhanced multimedia experience. However, the Dimensity 7050 chip is more suitable for everyday users than performance enthusiasts. While the primary camera performs well, the lack of an ultra-wide angle lens is disappointing. The battery life and charging capabilities meet expectations, and the software is feature-rich but comes with excessive bloatware. Alternative options include the Lava Agni 2 for clean software, a wide-angle camera, and the Poco X5 Pro for gaming enthusiasts.

Priced at Rs 18,999, the Samsung Galaxy M34 5G is an excellent smartphone which comes with a 6.5-inch Super display. The screen has a 120Hz refresh rate. The device ships with an octa-core Exynos 1280 SoC which can handle all the basic tasks. The smartphone boots Android 13 out of the box, and it is promised to receive 4 years of Android OS updates and 5 years of security patches. The device packs a 6,000mAh battery. However, it only supports 25W fast charging, and the charger doesn't come included in the box. Overall, the Galaxy M34 5G is a good smartphone, considering that you get a good battery life, AMOLED display, and it's also going to receive four years of Android OS updates.

The iQOO Neo 7 Pro is a gaming-oriented smartphone, perfect for avid gamers. Although design isn't its primary focus, the faux-leather approach stands out. The display is exceptional for gamers and content creators alike. While the software is decent, a few pre-installed apps can be bothersome. Nevertheless, the excellent battery and fast charging overshadow the inconvenience. The camera performance is decent, surpassing its predecessor.

The Vivo V29 Pro is a camera powerhouse, tailor-made for content creators and photo buffs. But it's not just about the camera - it rocks a premium look without breaking the bank. The Pro version boasts a slick 6.78-inch curved AMOLED display with a buttery-smooth 120Hz refresh rate, perfect for binge-watching or scrolling through your feed. Plus, no bleeding colours at the edges, although it could use a tad more brightness in sunlight. On the camera front, the V29 Pro packs a punch with a 50MP primary, a 12MP portrait, and 8MP ultra-wide shooters on the rear, complemented by a sharp 50MP selfie camera. Expect true-to-life images without over-processing. Performance-wise, the phone houses the MediaTek Dimensity 8200 SoC, handling everyday tasks with ease, from gaming to multitasking, all without any hiccups. And with a rather decent 4600mAh battery, you'll go all day without a hitch. Oh, and say goodbye to bloatware - FunTouch 13 based on Android 13 lets you declutter your phone. If you prioritise top-notch camera capabilities, exceptional battery life, and a curved display, the Vivo V29 Pro is a must-have.

Samsung Galaxy Note 20 Ultra 5G gives you flagship performance with the best internals that money can buy right now. You also get S Pen for support that enhances the use case of the device and the cameras in tow will offer top quality photos in all conditions. That said, the phone's battery supports 25W charging only and the camera bump at the back can be annoying. All in all, a Note-worthy device from Samsung in the flagship arena.

With its unique faux leather back, 200-megapixel camera, curved OLED panel, an adequately powerful processor and insanely fast charging speeds, the Realme 11 Pro+ hits the customer sentiments at the right spots. It does have a slightly underpowered SoC, but the rest of the package surpasses that.

The Lava Blaze Curve 5G impresses with its premium design, curved AMOLED display, smooth performance thanks to the Dimensity 7050 chipset, and reliable battery life, making it a standout choice for budget-conscious consumers seeking style and functionality without compromise.

Looking for a solid mid-range smartphone with premium features and long-term software support? The Samsung Galaxy A34 is a fantastic option to consider. With a smooth 120Hz AMOLED display and sleek, flagship-inspired design, it offers excellent value for its price point. However, it's worth noting that the phone doesn't come with a charger in the box and doesn't support fast charging, which may be a dealbreaker for some users. If you're looking for other compelling alternatives in this price range, you might want to check out the iQOO Neo 7 or Redmi Note 12 Pro Plus.

Apple iPhone 12 Mini is the smallest model from this year's lineup. But there is nothing inferior about its features and performance. It runs on iOS 14, powered by the latest A14 bionic processor and the cameras are pretty good at the back. The battery life benefits from improved power management and you also have wireless charging to fall back upon. However, storage is still not expandable, the front cameras not matching the price tag, and so is the fast charging speed.

The Realme C53 sports a 6.74-inch display with a 90Hz refresh rate. The display panel has a 90 percent screen-to-body ratio and the display quality is good for enjoying multimedia content. The phone is powered by Unisoc T616 SoC, which can handle basic everyday activities. The device has got a 108MP camera which captures average shots. The device also has a microSD card slot and a 18W fast charging support. If your priority is a good display, design, and battery life, you can go for Realme C53. In the same price range, you also can consider Realme C55 which offers better chipsets, and even 33W fast charging.

The OPPO Reno 11 boasts a gorgeous display, captures great photos and packs a marathon battery but slightly underwhelming performance paired with buggy software holds it back from becoming a true value for money.

Poco X3 Pro is the ideal mid-range phone in the market for power-hungry users. It has pretty much everything you need. Big screen with support for 120Hz refresh rate, Android 11-based software, decent cameras on both sides and IP rating for splash-proof resistance. You also get long battery backup with 33W fast charging supported. However, the only drawbacks are hybrid storage slot and a bulky design can be uncomfortable to use. Poco X3 Pro is a definite choice for buyers.

The Galaxy A73 5G comes with a 6.7-inch AMOLED display that has Full HD+ resolution. The display panel has a 120Hz refresh rate and Corning Gorilla Glass 5 protection. The Snapdragon 778G equipped with the A73 5G offers decent performance. The handset runs Android 12 out of the box. The device supports 25W fast charging. However, the device is a bit pricey in India. In the Rs 41,999 price range, the OnePlus 9 RT 5G or the iQOO 9 5G can be a better option compared to the Galaxy A73 5G.

iPhone 14 Pro isn't a regular upgrade this year like the iPhone 14. The Pro model packs enough bells and whistles to keep it relevant for the current times. The biggest upgrade has to be the cameras, and we are impressed. The display on the Pro is the best we have seen on phones this year, and its performance is top-notch. But the battery department is where things get slightly disheartening.

If you're in the market for a smartphone suited for everyday use such as scrolling through social media apps, light gaming, and browsing, then the Vivo Y28 presents itself as a budget-friendly 5G option worth considering. Display-wise, users get a 6.56-inch IPS LCD screen, which falls within the average spectrum. The device is powered by the MediaTek Dimensity 6020 SoC, which provides slightly lacklustre performance when compared to some of its peers. When it comes to photography, it boasts a 50MP main camera and a 2MP depth camera on the rear, accompanied by an 8MP selfie shooter. While the images captured by the phone are satisfactory and somewhat true-to-life, selfie enthusiasts may notice a smoothing effect applied to the skin. The phone runs on FuntouchOS 13, based on Android 13, which comes with a lot of bloatware. They can send you those pesky notifications you didn't sign up for. The phone houses a 5000mAh battery, which will last for over a day with light usage. So, if you're in the market for an affordable 5G smartphone with standard capabilities, the Vivo Y28 5G stands as a solid contender.

The new Samsung Galaxy S21 does pack a punch, when it comes to the specifications and features. The device sports a large 6.2-inches Dynamic AMOLED display, a 64MP triple camera setup, and a decent 4000mAh battery with 25W fast charging support. It also comes with wireless charging 15W and reverse wireless charging 4.5W. Plus, the device packs powerful hardware configuration making it a worthy handset to own. The device does not support expandable memory via a microSD card slot. Given the price point, the device is a good option to purchase.

The Motorola Razr 50 Ultra, the flagship in the lineup, boasts the largest cover display in the flip market, packed with features in a sleek design. It offers solid battery life and performs well in good lighting, but for better performance, consider the Samsung Galaxy Z Flip6. While versatile, the Razr 50 Ultra has its quirks - audio issues, performance glitches, and no ultra-wide camera.

The Phantom V Flip excels in many areas, with a good inner display, impressive build quality, and competitive camera performance in daylight. It boasts good battery life and includes a charger in the box too. However, its mid-range chipset struggles with heavy gaming but outperforms the similarly-priced Razr 40 in benchmarks. The cover screen could be more practical as well. To sum up, the Tecno Phantom V Flip may not the best in its price range, but it offers an excellent value for those looking to make a statement or hang up on calls in style. The Moto Razr 40 is another alternative, but has its own drawbacks.

The OnePlus 10R comes loaded with a host of interesting features and specifications. The latest device from OnePlus comes with a premium design language, which is quite comfortable when you hold it in your hand. The handset also offers reliable performance, though the camera is not its strongest point. That said, if you are looking for a bloatware-free experience and stable performance, then you can go with the OnePlus 10R

mobile_name: Samsung Galaxy Note 10 Plus (Galaxy Note 10 Pro)
expert_view: The Galaxy Note 10 Plus is among the best high-end phones you can buy right now. Apart from the missing headphone jack, there's nothing else that I could think of, being particularly bad on the phone. It has an eye-catching design, it feels thinner than it actually is, and it has the best display in the smartphone business, as of 2019. The Exynos 9825 brings speed and smoothness, and One UI is one of the nicest feeling software in the business. All four cameras on the phone are excellent. While the Note 10 Plus can't quite reach the level and clarity of the P30 Pro's camera in low-light conditions, it more than makes up for it in the video recording capability. The phone has dozens of useful features, including Samsung Pay and water resistance. Battery life is good, too, but not among the best in the business. All-in-all, it is one of the best phones released in 2019.

The Motorola Edge Plus features a 6.67-inch OLED curved display with a 165Hz refresh rate, ensuring smooth animations and scrolling experience. The display is crisp and sharp, enhancing the visual experience. The Edge Plus has a glass back panel with a matte finish, giving it a premium look and feel. Its build quality is impressive. Powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 SoC, the phone effortlessly handles everyday tasks and intensive gaming. The Edge Plus has a 5100mAh battery that supports a full day of moderate to heavy usage. It also supports 68W fast charging, allowing the phone to charge fully in about 30 minutes. For photography, the phone includes a 50MP main camera, a 50MP ultra-wide camera, and a 12MP telephoto camera. On the front, it features a 60MP selfie camera. The photos are rich in detail with accurate colours. Running on Android 13, the Edge Plus offers a near-stock experience, providing smooth performance, balanced capabilities, and good battery life.

The Samsung Galaxy S20 Ultra is one of the best devices by Samsung. The camera setup on the device provides excellent performance while taking photos in low-light conditions. The Exynos 9 Octa 990 chipset delivers good performance for its price tag. The device also packs a big 5000mAh Li-ion battery which seems good.

The Poco C65 comes with MediaTek Helio G85 chipset, a 50MP triple rear camera setup, a 5,000mAh battery, and 18W fast charging. While all this is common for a budget phone, it stands out because it undercuts the competition with its price. The Poco C65 offers a good daily performance with a battery that should last up to a day. There's 18W charging support as well, is about as much as the market standard. The 90Hz refresh rate of the display could have been higher, considering many budget smartphones offer a 120Hz screen these days. Given the phone runs MIUI OS, it comes with heavy customisation and bloatware, which might be an issue for some users.  If you're on a tight budget and are looking for a smartphone strictly under the Rs 10,000 price point, then Poco C65 is one of the best options to consider. It offers a good screen, a decent camera system, and a modest performance.

The Tecno Camon 30 boasts good cameras, a smooth AMOLED display, and respectable battery life. However, its performance, driven by the MediaTek Dimensity 7020 SoC, falls short of expectations on the gaming front, but for everyday life usage and multi-tasking, this phone is more than sufficient.  The Camon 30 has few drawbacks too. That said, when considering your options, if you seek a smartphone that excels in everyday tasks, offers impressive camera capabilities, and delivers decent battery life, then the Tecno Camon 30 5G is an ideal choice.
The on-paper specs of the Nord 2T aren't going to impress you much, and it feels it was launched a couple of months too late, but then it caters to a very different audience.

Realme GT 5G has a lot going for it. It's a power-packed device under Rs 40K with Snapdragon 888 chipset which is impressive. This variant gets 8GB RAM with 128GB storage, which sadly is not expandable. The Super AMOLED display gets 120Hz refresh rate support which is slick and you'll love playing games on it. The OS still has bloatware which is not ideal and the primary camera at the back is a mixed bag. And finally, the 4500mAh battery has a lot to thank for the 65W charging speed for quick juice up. Definite choice for power users, but stay away if you like clicking quality photos.

The Samsung Galaxy S23+ offers a compelling flagship experience, making it an attractive choice for those seeking an "S" series device within the Samsung ecosystem. The entire S23 series stands out with its unique and appealing design, particularly among younger users. In addition, it delivers impressive performance, albeit with unremarkable camera upgrades. While battery life has improved, the slow charging speeds remain a drawback.

Vivo Y20 features 6.5-inch display and the hardware is paired with 4GB of RAM and 64GB storage that is further expandable. It comes triple rear cameras that is decent for the price and a reliable selfie camera. But more importantly, the phone gets 5,000mAh battery with 18W charging speed. However, the screen resolution and hardware on board are a big downer for the price and with the existing competition.

The Poco M6 boasts a 6.74-inch LCD screen with a 90Hz refresh rate. While the water drop-style notch might not be to everyone's taste, the viewing experience is moderately acceptable, given the price. The design is clean and minimalistic. On the back, you'll find a 50MP primary AI camera and a 2MP depth camera, while the front features a 5MP selfie camera. The image colours are saturated, but there's a noticeable amount of noise. The overall image quality is acceptable, though nothing exceptional. Powered by the MediaTek Dimensity 6100+ SoC, the Poco M6 performs well, handling everyday and heavy tasks with a few restrictions. It has a 5000mAh battery that supports 18W charging, although the phone has a 10W charging adapter. The battery life lasts an entire day with light to moderate usage. In summary, the Poco M6 is a solid choice in the budget segment.

The OPPO A78 comes with a 6.56-inch IPS LCD display that has HD+ resolution. The device is equipped with octa-core Dimensity 700 processor which offers good performance. The camera on the device takes some good images, thanks to a 50MP sensor. The phone also has 5G support and it runs Android 13 OS out of the box. If the display isn't a concern for you, you can go for the OPPO A78 considering that you are getting 5G, Android 13 OS, and an octa-core Dimensity 700 SoC.

The POCO F5 impresses with its powerful performance, thanks to the Qualcomm Snapdragon 7 Plus Gen 2 chipset and 12 GB of RAM. Its stunning 6.67-inch AMOLED display, triple rear camera setup, and long-lasting battery make it a great choice for users seeking a feature-packed smartphone.
The Reno8 Pro performs decently but has a more impressive battery life and charging chops, although we wish the cameras could live up to the hype.

If you're in the market for an affordable 5G phone with a nice smooth display, vegan leather back finish, and a 5000mAh battery pack, then the Moto G34 5G could be your go-to choice. It boasts a 6.5-inch HD+ IPS LCD display with a punch-hole notch and 120Hz refresh rate, this phone ensures visibility even under bright sunlight. Snapping pics is a breeze with its 50MP primary camera, 8MP ultra-wide, and 16MP selfie cam. At this price point, users get a pretty decent camera. Its Snapdragon 695 SoC is a bit dated, but it can handle light tasks just fine. Plus, with My UX based on Android 14, the interface is clean and clutter-free. While the phone includes a 20W charging adapter in the box, it's only compatible with 18W charging, which may confuse buyers. For the price, you're getting a bang for your buck with decent speakers, killer battery life, and a subtle, near-stock UI.

cpu: Snapdragon 7 Gen 1 Accelerated Edition Octa core
expert_view: The Honor 90 stands out for its outstanding display and elegant design, making it a compelling choice. But it falls short in handling more demanding tasks, revealing its limitations.

OnePlus Nord is one of the most affordable 5G-ready phone in the market right now. It comes with a 90Hz AMOLED display, features quad rear cameras and gets a solid 4,115mAh battery with 30W fast charging support. However, the storage is not further expandable and it doesn't come with a headphone jack.

Apple iPhone 13 Pro is the first device from the brand to feature Super Retina OLED 120Hz display which changes everything in terms of experience. The phone comes powered by the new A15 Bionic chipset which is fast and reliable, along with 8GB RAM and 128GB storage. The cameras have improved in quality, especially in low light. The front camera is a good bet too. The battery life sees an increase as well. However, you cannot expand storage, there is no headphone jack and for this price 20W fast charging speed is not ideal. Buy the iPhone 13 Pro is you're upgrading from 2 year-old model or any Android device.

The Vivo Y18 features a 6.56-inch LCD screen with a 90Hz refresh rate, providing an acceptable viewing experience and moderately smooth scrolling. Powered by the MediaTek Helio G85 SoC, the phone handles everyday tasks such as calling, texting, scrolling through Instagram, and watching YouTube videos well, with only minor lags and stutters. However, intensive games like BGMI and Call of Duty: Mobile can only be played at the lowest settings and crashed multiple times during our testing. In contrast, casual games like Subway Surfers and 2048 run smoothly on this device. The phone has a 50MP primary camera and 0.08MP secondary camera on the back, and an 8MP front camera for selfies. The photo quality is average but sufficient for basic needs. It is equipped with a 5000mAh battery that supports 15W charging, which is relatively slow. The device runs on Funtouch OS 14, based on Android 14, and can feel somewhat laggy at times. Overall, considering its features and performance, the Vivo Y18 is a solid choice in the under-10K price segment.

iPhone 14 Plus packs a large screen that is found only on the Pro Max version. It packs all the bells and whistles to suit any customer, whether a pro user or one who needs a balanced package. The battery performance of the 14 Plus is unmatchable, even when Android flagships are considered.

The Google Pixel 8 Pro features a matte body finish that makes it easy to hold, and the device feels quite compact. It has a 6.7-inch OLED display that remains bright even under glaring sunlight. The display offers a 120Hz refresh rate, ensuring smooth animations and an impressive user experience. Powered by the Tensor G3 SoC, the phone boasts significant AI capabilities and handles everyday tasks efficiently. However, its gaming performance may not meet expectations, as the phone tends to heat up during extended gameplay sessions. The Pixel 8 Pro has a 50MP primary camera and a 48MP ultra-wide camera. While the primary camera shows minimal improvements over the Pixel 7 Pro, the tones are cooler. The phone excels in low-light photography, which is a notable advantage. It has a 5050mAh battery and supports 30W charging, although the charger is not included in the box. Running on Android 14, the 8 Pro offers a pure Android experience. Therefore, if you are looking for a smartphone with excellent camera capabilities, a stock Android experience, and advanced AI features, the Pixel 8 Pro is a strong contender.

Oppo A79 5G's highlight reel includes a unique rear panel texture, flat edge design and a 5,000mAh battery. When you have a deeper look, things get a little interesting. The OPPO A79 5G is powered by MediaTek 6020 SoC, which is also the chipset that powers the Lava Blaze 2 5G, which is about half its price. Its 50MP dual rear camera setup is decent for both, night and day shots, and the display is also decently responsive at 90Hz.    Oppo A79 5G is priced slightly on the higher side at Rs 19,999, so those open to options are recommended to go for realme Narzo 60 5G, which is priced slightly lower at Rs 15,999 and comes with slightly higher specifications on paper, like a Super AMOLED display, a 64MP primary rear camera, and a 16MP front camera.

Infinix Zero 5G is a dark horse device that deserves your attention. It has a 120Hz display built into a stylish body and it supports 5G thanks Dimensity 900 SoC. You get reliable performance with 8GB RAM and 128GB expandable storage is good to have for most users. Even the cameras will surprise you, and the battery life keeps you ticking. Only drawbacks are no AMOLED display, and Android 11 OS.

The OnePlus 12R closely resembles its older sibling, the OnePlus 12. It features a glossy back panel that does get covered in fingerprints easily. Still, the phone is comfortable to hold and well-built. This phone features a 6.78-inch ProXDR display with a 120Hz refresh rate. The display is bright and offers a great viewing experience. Powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 SoC, which is slightly older, the chipset handles everyday tasks and heavy gaming efficiently. If you're looking for a smartphone that balances performance and gaming, the 12R is a strong choice. At the back, the 12R boasts a 50MP primary camera, an 8MP ultra-wide camera, and a 2MP macro camera. The photos are crisp and detailed, but if you prioritise advanced photography features, you might prefer the OnePlus 12. The phone has a 5500mAh battery and comes with an 80W charging adapter. You can expect a full day of battery life with light to moderate use. Overall, the OnePlus 12R offers a flagship-level experience at a more affordable price.

The Samsung Galaxy M14 5G gets the basics right and provides a bunch of features which are typical of this price range. The display quality is quite good for content viewing, but it showcases an outdated design. On the other hand, the Exynos 1330 performs quite well in daily usage and normal gaming. Moreover, the battery life on the Galaxy M14 is quite impressive, with seven hours of screen on time. As for the cameras, the primary and selfie optics prove to be worthy.

Oppo Reno 6 is the latest from the brand in India, and looks to appeal with its wide set of features. At Rs 35,000 the phone gets an AMOLED 90Hz display, comes powered by the new MediaTek Dimensity 900 chipset with 8GB RAM for solid performance. It has a triple rear camera with 64MP primary sensor, but the others are not effective enough for this price range. The device provides long battery backup with 65W fast charging as well. However, it has no headphone, no way to expand memory and only 90Hz at this price. Definitely worth looking at other options in this range from Xiaomi, iQOO and more.

The Apple iPhone 14 Pro Max is the most expensive iPhone from the company. The phone is ideal for those who want to experience the best of Apple features. The latest iPhone is equipped with a large 6.7-inch display that makes it a great device to watch videos and play graphics-intensive games. The model is powered by the ultra-fast Apple A16 Bionic CPU, which is one of the best chipsets in the industry. Moreover, it also packs excellent photographic abilities because of its 48MP triple-camera system. If you're in the market for a new iPhone and want the best experience imaginable, the iPhone 14 Pro Max is the way to go.

Even though the V25 Pro is also being sold online, customers buying a smartphone from an offline retail store prefer the in-hand feel more than the specs, and that might be the space the V25 Pro might crack.

The Infinix Zero Flip impresses as the brand's first flip phone. It boasts a large cover display and an excellent primary camera, ideal for self-portraits. Its wide internal screen and great audio enhance content consumption, backed by a long-lasting battery. However, the hinge could be smoother, and the UI needs refinement in future updates. Despite these first-gen drawbacks, it's a solid choice for flip phone enthusiasts seeking style and performance.

The Vivo T2 is a solid phone with an impressive AMOLED display, fast charging capability and a sleek, lightweight design. However, it falls short with no stereo speakers, some pre-installed bloatware and the absence of an ultra-wide angle lens.

The Samsung Galaxy M51 is a powerful smartphone and ships with an excellent specs sheet. The device is a bit bulky weighing 213 grams, and it can be attributed to a heavy battery. Apart from that, the phone flaunts a stunning AMOLED plus display, a 64MP Quad camera setup and a powerful processor. The main highlight is the monster 7000mAh battery. Given the features, the Samsung Galaxy M51 is a good device to own in the mid-range segment.

The Nokia X30 may not be the most affordable option on the market, with an MSRP of Rs.48,999 but it does have a few features that make it stand out. While the choice of chipset may result in mediocre performance and limited video recording capabilities, the 3-year warranty and guaranteed software updates for the same period of time could be appealing to those who prefer to keep their phones for as long as possible. If you're considering buying the Nokia X30, we would recommend exploring alternative options in a similar price range.

The Vivo X Fold 3 Pro is a fantastic foldable phone. It looks good, feels good, performs well, charges up quick, has remarkable battery life and takes some stunning shots.   The Rs 1,59,999 is steep, no doubt, but it can also double up as a laptop and tablet replacement.     That said, Vivo still needs to polish their UI.

The POCO F4 5G is one of the best options you can get in this price segment. The handset comes with a premium design language and offers a brillant display. The handset also delivers flagship-grade performance, all thanks to the Snapdragon 870 processor. The cameras are versatile as well and deliver good results in different lighting conditions.

Realme C55 is yet another great smartphone from the brand. The handset offers some great features and top-notch specifications at this price point. Whether be it large Full HD+ display, the power-packed MediaTek Helio G88 chipset or 33W fast charging support, the Realme C55 surely stands out of the crowd with its interesting features and specifications.

OnePlus 9 Pro offers a superior experience as compared to the earlier versions of OnePlus smartphones. The device's notable features are the 6.7-inch Fluid AMOLED display and impressive quad cameras featuring a 48MP+50MP+8MP+2MP configuration. The 16MP selfie-shooting lens at the front captures elegant selfies. Fueling the smartphone is a 4500mAh battery; aided by a 65W Warp charge, it does not take much time to refill the battery. The phone does not support expandable memory, and users have to contend with 128GB of internal memory.

The Vivo T2x features a 6.58-inch FHD+ IPS LCD screen that offers an average viewing experience. This phone is powered by the MediaTek Dimensity 6020 SoC, which handles multitasking between apps well and provides a good day-to-day experience. It is not built for heavy gaming, but casual games can be easily played. The phone has a 50MP primary camera and a 2MP macro camera at the back, and an 8MP front camera for selfies. The photos taken with this phone are good for its price range, though there is some noise in daylight shots, which is acceptable. The phone packs a 5000mAh battery and supports 18W charging, which is relatively slow. The Vivo T2x runs on Funtouch OS 13, based on Android 13, and comes with bloatware that can be removed for a cleaner user experience. The Vivo T2x is a budget smartphone that ticks almost all the boxes in its price segment.

The Samsung Galaxy Z Flip 6 is undeniably a stylish and compact device that packs a punch. Its performance is flagship-level, and the camera, while not perfect, captures decent shots. The AI features, though promising, require a bit of user familiarisation. It carries forward the same design from the Flip 5, but works on its durability by attaining an IP certification.

The OPPO Reno 6 Pro 5G comes with a 6.5-inch AMOLED display and is powered by Dimensity 1200 SoC. The device has a average ultra-wide-angle lens and macro camera. The phone lacks stereo speakers. It packs a 4500mAh battery which offers superfast 65W fast charging. The handset isn't a significant upgrade over the Reno5 Pro. In the similar Rs 39,990 price range, you can go for the OnePlus 9R, iQOO 7, or the Mi 11X Pro 5G.

Apple iPhone 12 Pro Max is the ideal flagship device for 2020 but with an exorbitant price tag. It has the latest A14 Bionic chipset that gives top-end performance with the paired 6GB RAM. You get ample storage and the new triple rear cameras get even better this year. The Retina OLED screen is the icing on the cake with a battery backup that'll satisfy most people. However, at this price, the phone offers no high refresh rate, storage is still not expandable, iOS 14 not the best for one-hand use, and the battery only supports 18W fast charging.

The Reno 10 Pro Plus is a well-rounded option at an affordable price. Its sleek design catches your attention, and the vibrant display keeps you captivated. The camera upgrades are impressive, especially the telephoto lens. The performance is excellent, too, more than adequate for heavy-duty tasks. However, the excessive pre-installed apps are a drawback, especially at this price.

The Realme C67 5G is a value-oriented smartphone with the mid-tier MediaTek Dimensity 6100+ SoC, a 120Hz LCD display and a dual 50MP rear camera at a starting price of Rs 13,999. It comes with up to 6GB RAM and 128GB expandable storage. It can handle most daily tasks as well as gaming with medium graphics. In the camera department, the Realme C67 5G fares well with competitors in the price range. The 5,000mAh battery can last a full day's worth of use and charges it with the bundled 33W SUPERVOOC charger. However, do look out for bloatware and heavily customised UI as this could be a deal-breaker for many. Realme C67's appeal lies in its affordability, making it an excellent choice for users on a tight budget who prioritize essential smartphone features like a decent processor and cameras in addition to a good battery life.

The Vivo V27 Pro brings style and substance with its powerful processor, impressive camera capabilities, and colour-changing design, but its lack of IP certification, stereo speakers and higher price point may leave some buyers wanting more.

The Tecno Pova 6 Pro 5G offers a stunning 6.78-inch AMOLED display, lasts two days on a single charge thanks to the massive 6000mAh battery, and a unique design with LED lights, all without crossing the Rs 20,000 mark. However, occasional performance stutters and low-light camera capabilities keep it from greatness.

mobile_name: Samsung Galaxy M15 Prime Edition 8GB RAM

expert_view: The Samsung Galaxy S21 FE features a 6.4-inch AMOLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate, providing a pleasing viewing experience. Powered by the Exynos 2100 SoC, the phone performs admirably. Games like BGMI and Call of Duty: Mobile run smoothly, adding to the entertainment value. The stereo speakers on the S21 FE produce excellent sound quality, which is a bonus. In terms of battery life, the phone houses a 4500mAh battery, lasting almost a day with light to moderate usage. Regarding the cameras, there's a 12MP main camera with OIS, an 8MP telephoto camera, and a 12MP ultra-wide camera on the rear. For selfies, there's a 32MP front-facing camera. Daylight shots are vibrant and detailed, but the ultra-wide camera lacks autofocus. The selfie camera captures natural photos with consistent skin tones. Low-light photography on this device brightens images, sometimes excessively. Overall, the Galaxy S21 FE ticks most boxes with a few drawbacks. If you're looking for a smartphone with solid performance, a premium design, and excellent battery life, then the S21 FE is worth considering.

The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 4 is the South Korean smartphone manufacturer's finest innovation. The handset not only offers flagship-grade features and specifications, but it also comes with a unique folding mechanism that has redefined the smartphone industry. The handset is loaded with the latest Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Plus Gen processor and offers reliable cameras. The phone also offers a crisp display and comes loaded with a 120Hz adaptive AMOLED display. If price is not a factor, the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 4 is one of the greatest alternatives available right now.

The Realme 10 Pro+ has focused on the display factor and introduced the Dimensity 1080 SoC to this price segment. The device runs well in our day-to-day usage, but we noticed a disparity in the refresh rate in certain apps. On the other hand, the cameras are decent and click detailed photos, and it has support for fast charging, up to 65W.
Overall, if you do not mind the bloatware and are looking for a device that can perform well, charge fast and take good photos with its selfie camera, go with the OPPO Reno 8 5G.

The Vivo Y100 is priced at under Rs 25,000 in India. The device has a sleek design, a powerful battery, and a decent camera setup. The smartphone offers faster performance, thanks to Dimensity 900 SoC. The handset also sports a 6.38-inch AMOLED display. On the software side of things, the phone runs the latest Android 13 OS. However, the UI consists of some pre-installed bloatware. The device also offers 44W fast charging and it also has 5G support. If you are looking for a smartphone with the latest Android 13 OS, good battery life, 5G, and faster performance, you can go for the Vivo Y100.

The Itel S24 impresses with its battery life, display, and premium design featuring color-changing capabilities, likely to attract today's youth. However, it falls short in low-light photography. Despite lacking 5G, it offers intriguing features at its price point. Still, the Itel S24 is a solid choice for a secondary smartphone with dependable battery life, aiming to make its mark in the sub-15K price range. The question remains: will you prioritise additional features or compromise on certain aspects?

The Nothing Phone (2a) Plus is Rs 4,000 more than the Phone (2a). While both share a similar design and display, the Plus model offers better gaming performance (nearly 90 fps), faster charging, longer battery life, and superior camera quality. If these features matter to you, the Phone (2a) Plus justifies the extra cost. It also competes well with the Motorola Edge 50 Pro, Realme GT 6T, and POCO F6. However, if gaming is your top priority, consider the Realme GT 6T or POCO F6.

Oppo A53 2020 packs a 6.5-inch bright display with support for 90Hz refresh rate. It comes with 4GB of RAM, features a decent set of triple rear cameras, latest ColorOS version over Android 10 and a big capacity battery. However, the Snapdragon 460 chipset offers mediocre performance for the price and in this segment, you have plenty of other options to look at.

In the affordable smartphone market, the Samsung Galaxy F14 5G model presents a desirable balance of design and specifications. The phone's large 6.6-inch display is ideal for viewing content from a variety of platforms. Considering the price range of under Rs 15,000, the camera appears to be satisfactory. Additionally, the Galaxy F14 is equipped with a generous 6,000mAh battery that can last for a full day with some battery power remaining. In general, it is a suitable choice to consider in this price category.

The Vivo X90 Pro is a true flagship with a fantastic rear camera setup, a rear panel texture that's downright addictive, and super-fast charging. FunTouch OS is cleaner than ever, making it a joy to use. While it's missing a telephoto camera, low-light glare can be an issue and battery life is alright. However, for the price, it's hard to beat the value the X90 Pro offers.

The OnePlus 9 (128GB) is a power-packed device with excellent specifications under the hood. The phone comes with a 6.55-inches Fluid AMOLED display with a 120 Hz screen refresh rate. The device comes powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 888 octa-core processor paired with 8GB of RAM. The phone packs excellent camera configuration on the rear (48MP+50MP+2MP) and a single 16MP front camera. The storage configuration is 128GB and is non-expandable. As for the cons, the phone lacks an official IP rating, does not have an expandable memory option, and does not support wireless charging.

OnePlus Open competes well with the Galaxy Z Fold 5 in terms of performance, cameras, displays, and battery life. The displays are top-notch with no major differences between them, and the nearly creaseless design is commendable. The Open handles multitasking and heavy apps smoothly, even though the Z Fold 5 still leads in benchmark tests. The camera, especially the 3x lens, delivers impressive results, and the battery and charging performance surpasses the competition. However, OnePlus should consider adding stylus support, optimising apps for the foldable display, and making the price more reasonable. Overall, the Open marks a strong debut for OnePlus in the nascent category of foldables, and fits well into their lineup.

The Galaxy A33 5G boasts a 6.43-inch AMOLED display that has a 90Hz refresh rate. The device is powered by Exynos 1280 chipset which offers lag-free performance. The camera takes some good images, thanks to a 48MP sensor. The device runs Android 12 out of the box. A 5,000mAh battery equipped with the A33 5G offers long-lasting battery life. However, the device supports only 25W fast charging and it is pricer compared to the competition.

Jio Bharat phone is an excellent 4G feature phone launched by Reliance Jio.  It offers essential features like UPI payments, JioCinema, Jio Saavn and includes affordable recharge plans, making it a good option for those who wish to have compact phone at cheapest prices.

The Apple iPhone SE 2 might not offer the bells and whistles that Android smartphones in the same category offer. However, if you look at the overall package, the iPhone SE 2 makes much more sense buying. It has an excellent display, a capable rear camera, am excellent front camera, fastest and smoothest performance in the segment, great stereo speaker quality, long battery backup, and fast charging. It is also one of the very few newly-launched devices in the segment to offer IP68 water and dust resistance. Plus, you get to enjoy Apple's clean and robust iOS 13 OS and brand's software ecosystem. What else do you need in a smartphone?

The OnePlus Nord 2 CE 5G comes with a 6.43-inch AMOLED display. The device is equipped with Dimensity 900 SoC and 6GB of RAM, which offers flawless performance. The device sport a 64MP triple-camera setup, which takes some good images. The handset supports up to 65W fast charging support. The smartphone lacks stereo speakers support and it runs older Android 11 version. If you are looking for a smartphone with 65W fast charging support and best hardware, you can consider buying OnePlus Nord CE 2 5G.

The Samsung Galaxy A23 5G is reasonably priced Samsung device on the market offers some interesting features. For the price, it has a new Qualcomm Snapdragon 695 chipset paired with 6GB of RAM. The phone also features a large display, expandable memory slot, decent cameras and also the latest version of Android 13 operating system. Despite only supporting 25W fast charging, the battery life is good. That being said, this phone offers fantastic value at its current price.

The iQOO Neo 7 is without a doubt a power-packed device. This should serve most of the people in the market. Especially, people looking for a phone that can last an entire day without much fuss. Although, if cameras are your thing, you might want to look elsewhere.

The Samsung Galaxy S22+ is a pocket rocket with a comfortable form factor, fantastic display and user interface. Heating and throttling issues are prevalent, but that doesn't keep it from being addictive.

The Vivo X90 5G is a premium offering from Vivo priced at Rs 59,999 in India. The smartphone offers impressive specifications such as an AMOLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate and 1300 nits brightness. Thanks to the Dimensity 9200 SoC, the device offers excellent performance. The smartphone offers 120W fast charging support, and it boots latest Android 13 OS. The Vivo X90 5G is a value-for-money smartphone considering that you get a good display, processor, up to 120W fast charging support, and excellent cameras.

The Pixel 9 Pro XL feels like the new standout in the Pixel family. It nails the premium look - sleek design, sharp camera module, and a selfie camera that captures every detail, right down to skin texture and hair follicles. Plus, Google's signature AI magic is baked into the software, making the experience even smarter. But here's the catch - AI isn't just Google's thing anymore. Apple's got its own take with Apple Intelligence, and Samsung and OnePlus are hot on its heels. So, Pixel's exclusivity in AI is fading fast. Performance-wise, it doesn't lead the pack. If you need raw power, the Galaxy S24 Ultra might be your go-to. For photography, the Vivo X100 Pro and Xiaomi 14 Ultra are solid alternatives, though each has trade-offs. That said, if you value a clean interface, reliable everyday use, and a killer selfie camera, the XL price tag could still feel worth it.

While the OnePlus 8 comes out on top in terms of display quality, performance, software, and battery life experience, it lacks behind its competitors by a huge margin in terms of the rear as well as front camera performance.

The Asus ROG Phone 8 Pro features a 6.78-inch AMOLED display with a 165Hz refresh rate, similar to the Moto Edge Plus 2023. This high refresh rate ensures smooth display performance and excellent on-screen animations. The ROG Phone 8 Pro is powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 SoC, delivering an outstanding gaming experience. If you're looking for a dedicated gaming smartphone, this should be at the top of your list. The Asus ROG Phone 8 Pro includes a 50MP wide camera, a 32MP telephoto camera, and a 13MP ultra-wide camera on the back. It also offers a 32MP front camera for selfies. The phone has a robust 5500mAh battery and supports 65W fast charging, making it suitable for heavy use. Given its overall features, the Asus ROG Phone 8 Pro is a top-notch gaming device. However, its high price may make it less appealing to some buyers.

The itel P55 5G is the first 5G smartphone priced at under Rs 10,000 in India. The device has a 6.6-inch IPS LCD display. The display panel also has a 90Hz refresh rate. The device uses an octa-core Dimensity 6080 SoC which offers good performance. However, the camera on the device is average and the handset supports 18W charging. If you are looking for an entry-level 5G smartphone with good display and performance, then you can consider buying the itel P55 5G.

The POCO X6 is a great smartphone that offers a good mix of a capable display, lag-free performance, and fast charging battery. The phone also brings segment-leading features such as the new Snapdragon chipset, OIS support, and more. Overall, if you are looking for a no-nonsense smartphone without breaking the bank, then you should consider the POCO X6.

Vivo X70 Pro is another hard-core performance device from the company. It comes powered by Dimensity 1200 chipset with 8GB RAM and it has quality cameras at the back that offer decent results. The AMOLED 120Hz display is a treat for most eyes, and the design will appeal to you as well. Having said that, this phone lacks a memory card slot, doesn't get headphone jack and the battery life suffers in general. If you are in the market, definitely consider this one.

The Realme GT Neo 3 5G is probably one of the best smartphones you can buy right now. The smartphone comes with an interesting design language that is inspired by racing stripes. The device is powered by the flagship-grade MediaTek Dimensity 8100 processor and comes with some interesting gaming-centric features. These may include stainless steel vapour cooling, X-liner motor, and more. The phone also features good cameras that are capable of clicking detailed photos and videos in different conditions. Moreover, the 80W fast charging support is a great addition to this price segment as well.

The Redmi Note 12 Pro Plus brings about some meaningful upgrades. Its 200-megapixel camera brings unparalleled quality to the masses, the 120W charging is a meaningful addition to the feature package, and the Dimensity 1080 is a reasonable refresh in terms of performance. MIUI 13 can be a pain sometimes with its bugs, and there's still a bit of bloat present to take away some of the experience.

The Huawei Mate 20 pro is undoubtedly one of the best flagship phones one can buy in India. It also bears one of the best imaging setups we have seen, that even outclasses Google Pixel 3XL in some areas. The only smartphone that is currently competing against this phone is the Samsung Galaxy Note 9. While some might still choose to stick with a more 'trusted brand,' there is no denying that the Mate 20 Pro is the best bang for your buck flagship out there right now.

The Samsung Galaxy M53 is one of the best Samsung mobile phones you can get in this segment. The smartphone comes loaded with some really great camera features and offers a quad-camera setup with a 108MP primary sensor. The handset also packs a reliable MediaTek Dimensity 900 processor that handles most of the tasks you throw at it. Moreover, the phone comes with a premium design language and offers a Super AMOLED display for an enhanced viewing experience.

The OPPO Reno8 T has a premium build quality. The device boasts a 6.7-inch AMOLED display that has Full HD+ resolution and a 120Hz refresh rate. However, the display panel doesn't have HDR support. The phone features a 108MP camera, which captures some good images. However, in low lighting conditions, the photos taken with the device are average. The device offers a good battery, and the handset also offers 67W fast charging support. If your priority is the display, premium build, good battery life, and faster charging support, then you can go for the OPPO Reno8 T.

Xiaomi Mi 11X features a sleek and stylish design having a stunning display upfront. The handset comes powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 870 processor that supports lag-free performance. Together with 6GB RAM, the processor ensures thorough gaming performance. Although the device packs an impressive triple camera setup (48MP+8MP+5MP), it delivers a mediocre performance. The phone comes backed by a modest battery capacity of 4250mAh with 33W fast-charging support. As for the cons, the Mi 11X does not support expandable memory, and it lacks a 3.5mm headphone jack.

With a sprawling 6.62-inch AMOLED display, reliably powerful Snapdragon 870 SoC and 80W charging and maximum RAM capacity of 12GB, the Iqoo Neo 6 is clearly no slouch. But its looks, pricing and feature set may confuse some buyers. Find out where it stands in such a competitive market in our review.

The Realme 10 is equipped with a 6.4-inch AMOLED display. The phone packs an octa-core Helio G99 SoC which offers good performance. Thanks to a microSD card support, users can expand storage up to 1TB. The handset also supports up to 33W fast charging as well. However, the phone lacks 5G support and it still runs Android 12 out of the box. If the Android OS version and 5G aren't a concern, the Realme 10 is a good phone, considering that the device offers an AMOLED display, excellent performance, and 33W fast charging support.

Vivo X80 offers a flagship-grade performance and features at this price range. The smartphone packs a punch when it comes to the camera department and offers a plethora of camera modes to try. Moreover, the phone is loaded with a smooth design and versatile performance. On the downside, the user interface comes with some bloatware, which may hinder the overall performance. That said, if you are looking for a great camera smartphone in this price range, then you can consider the Vivo X80 5G.

The Redmi Note 8 is a solid upgrade over the already ultra-popular Redmi Note 7. It brings a faster processor (Snapdragon 665) and a quad-camera setup on the rear with 4K video recording. The phone looks good, works fast, and lasts longer, too. There's nothing not to like about this phone. About ads, MIUI 11 is going to get a one-switch option to turn off all push notifications and ads served by Xiaomi's system apps.

OnePlus Nord CE 5G is the affordable version that sits below the regular Nord launched last year. It supports 5G thanks to Snapdragon 750G SoC, and this variant gets 6GB RAM with 128GB storage which is not expandable. You do get back the headphone jack which is good but the plastic body is a downer in this price range these days. The cameras are average at best but thankfully the long battery life with fast charging helps in daily use cases. Nord CE 5G has touch competition in this price bracket right now.

The Motorola Edge 30 Ultra 5G boasts a 6.67-inch pOLED display that has a 144Hz refresh rate. The device offers excellent performance, thanks to Snapdragon 8 Plus Gen 1 SoC. The smartphone runs Android 12 out of the box with stock Android UI on top. The handset can capture 200MP images. It also supports up to 120W fast charging. However, the device is available only in a 128GB storage model and it lacks a microSD card. If that isn't a concern for you, the Motorola Edge 30 Ultra 5G is the device you can purchase, considering that you are getting a phone with pOLED 144Hz refresh rate display, excellent cameras, good hardware, and up to 120W fast charging.

The iPhone XS is indeed a significant improvement over its predecessor. However, it is priced too high for what it offers. As such, the iPhone XR makes for a more sensible purchase for those wanting to stick with the Apple ecosystem. If you are willing to consider an Android smartphone, the Galaxy Note 9 offers a better screen (without a notch), better cameras overall, a versatile S Pen, Samsung Pay, storage expansion, and a 3.5mm headphone jack for 30% cheaper price tag.

Vivo T1 is the latest mid-range 5G phone in the market that flatters to deceive. Just because it uses a 5G chipset other features have been compromised and we think you have better non-5G options in this price range you should consider buying.

The Asus ROG Phone 5s boasts a 6.78-inch OLED display with a 144Hz refresh rate. Thanks to the Snapdragon 888 Plus SoC and up to 12GB of RAM, the device offers excellent performance. The smartphone supports 65W fast charging and it packs a 6,000mAh battery. The device however lacks a microSD card support and has no IP rating. If you are looking for a gaming smartphone with top-notch hardware and excellent performance, you can go for the Asus ROG Phone 5s.

The Motorola Edge 30 Fusion comes with a premium design and offers good specifications. The phone packs premium hardware and offers a great user experience with its clean user interface. The camera offers good performance but it needs software refinement to improve low-light photography. The internal storage is limited to only 128GB. If you want a slim and light design along with a good performance and clean UI, the Motorola Edge 30 Fusion is a perfect choice.

The Motorola Edge 30 Pro 5G boasts a 6.7-inch P-OLED display that has a FHD+ resolution and a 120Hz refresh rate. The device is powered by Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 SoC. The smartphone packs 8GB of RAM and offers up to 68W fast charging support. However, the storage is limited to only 128GB as the handset lacks microSD card support. In a similar price range, you can explore other options such as iQOO 9, which offers more storage and 120W fast charging.

The Infinix GT Pro is a gaming-centric smartphone priced at under Rs 20,000. The device has an excellent design and an AMOLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate. Under the hood, the device is powered by an octa-core Dimensity 8050 SoC which offers excellent performance. The smartphone also has 5G support and a 32MP selfie camera which takes some good selfies. However, the device would be getting only one Android software update, and the camera performance on the device is average. If you are looking for a gaming-centric handset under Rs 20,000, then the Infinix GT Pro is worth buying. You get a lag-free performance, a good display with a 120Hz refresh rate, and clean software.
The Moto G84 5G offers a slim leather design, unique Pantone color options, 12GB RAM, and 256GB storage. It has a good camera but may lag behind in performance.

The design looks sleek and the smartphone is very light, weighing just 172g. The 6.4-inch AMOLED screen offers brighter images with good colour saturation. The device lacks a high refresh rate screen, which is seen quite often in most of the smartphones at this price segment. IPX4 and Schott Xensation glass protection are some of the useful features we find on this smartphone. OPPO F21 Pro 5G is a go-to smartphone for those looking for premium design and decent performance.

The Motorola Razr 50 is an impressive flip phone, with a big external display, more than decent cameras, and a clean and neat UI experience. For those who don't wish to spend a lot of money, it's a good option. Although, it could've included a high-end chipset and faster charging speeds.

The Realme Narzo 60 Pro offers a great combination of performance and aesthetics, making it an appealing choice. However, if you prioritize software and camera quality, the OnePlus Nord 3 might be a better option for you.

The Samsung Galaxy S23 is a premium offering from Samsung. The handset flaunts a 6.1-inch Dynamic AMOLED display that has Full HD+ resolution and a 120Hz refresh rate. The Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 chipset equipped with the device offers exceptional performance. The cameras on the device also takes some good images. The phone runs Android 13 out of the box with One UI 5.1 on top. However, the handset misses out 3.5mm audio jack, and it only offers 25W fast charging support. If you are primarily looking for a good display, faster performance, and latest Android version, you can go for the Samsung Galaxy S23.

The Xiaomi Redmi Note 10 packs a magnificent 6.43-inches Super AMOLED display, offering Full HD+ resolution of 1080 x 2400 pixels. The Corning Gorilla Glass v3 provides sturdy protection for the screen. The Qualcomm Snapdragon 678 chipset handles the processing work. The 48MP primary camera with an Exmor-RS CMOS sensor captures beautiful images. There are fewer cons to point out, one being the 60 Hz refresh rate display.

Vivo V20 offers a superb performance with the Snapdragon 720G processor that is made using the 8nm process technology. With the AMOLED display flaunting the device, pictures and videos will be crystal clear to view. The 44MP dual selfie camera with ultra-wide angle lens can take grouphies with all your loved ones with ease. What not! You have the 33W fast charger that comes in the box that can fully charge your Vivo V20 in a matter of minutes
